location.text:
::U3 p32 GR2 Present perfect vs past simple::[markdown]Match the phrases in bold in the following sentences to the respective tense and use. {
  =You can see she**'s been swimming** – her hair's still wet.                            -> Present perfect continuous - for a recent completed activity when the effects are still relevant
  =I **knew** almost everyone at the party.                                               -> Past simple - for a state in the past
  =Carol**'s been working** here for the last few weeks while Chloe's away having a baby. -> Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is temporary
  =I**'ve only worn** that shirt three times since I bought it.                           -> Present perfect - for an action repeated up to the present time
  =I**'ve been having** driving lessons for months but I'm not getting any better.        -> Present perfect continuous - to emphasise that an action has been going on for a long time
  =All my friends at school **played** football, not rugby.                               -> Past simple - for a habit in the past
  =Harry's birthday party **didn't end** until three in the morning.                      -> Past simple - for a finished event that happened at a specific time in the past
  =They**'ve been building** that house for ages and it's still only half-finished.       -> Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is not complete
}

result.title: U3 p32 GR2 Present perfect vs past simple

stem.text: Match the phrases in bold in the following sentences to the respective tense and use.

subquestion.text: You can see she**'s been swimming** – her hair's still wet.

matchPairs.subanswer: Present perfect continuous - for a recent completed activity when the effects are still relevant

subquestion.text: I **knew** almost everyone at the party.

matchPairs.subanswer: Past simple - for a state in the past

subquestion.text: Carol**'s been working** here for the last few weeks while Chloe's away having a baby.

matchPairs.subanswer: Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is temporary

subquestion.text: I**'ve only worn** that shirt three times since I bought it.

matchPairs.subanswer: Present perfect - for an action repeated up to the present time

subquestion.text: I**'ve been having** driving lessons for months but I'm not getting any better.

matchPairs.subanswer: Present perfect continuous - to emphasise that an action has been going on for a long time

subquestion.text: All my friends at school **played** football, not rugby.

matchPairs.subanswer: Past simple - for a habit in the past

subquestion.text: Harry's birthday party **didn't end** until three in the morning.

matchPairs.subanswer: Past simple - for a finished event that happened at a specific time in the past

subquestion.text: They**'ve been building** that house for ages and it's still only half-finished.

matchPairs.subanswer: Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is not complete
